title: Caroline Flack slams Jameela Jamil's criticism of The Surjury
text:
Caroline and Jameela aren’t on the same page (Picture: Getty)

Caroline Flack has slammed Jameela Jamil’s distaste for the Love Island presenter’s new show, The Surjury.

Last week The Good Place star Jameela compared the show to Black Mirror, and seems Caroline is none too pleased with the comparison.

In case you missed it, Caroline is the host of the upcoming Channel 4 series The Surjury, which will see people who want plastic surgery pitching their stories and requests to a group of strangers.

The jury will then decide who is granted their wishes to go under the knife.

Reacting to the show, Jameela wrote online: ‘Welp. Black Mirror is officially happening guys. It’s here.’

After the Flack Attack returned serve with a sassy quip, she’s now gone further in defending the programme.

‘As you know self image is a complicated, sensitive and personal subject,’ she wrote on Twitter overnight.

‘At the heart of this show are people not contestants who have sought help to want to better them selves in their own eyes.

‘Their stories deserve to be told and not ridiculed online.’

Her message followed Jameela’s response to Dr Tijion Esho, who said he pulled out of being the show’s doctor after discovering the whole premise.

Jameela wrote: ‘This is why I said it was like Black Mirror @carolineflack1.

Caroline is back with another hosting gig (Picture: Channel 4)roline flack

‘Because it’s a VERY surreal concept that (perhaps unintentionally) will prey on people’s insecurities. I think of the effect on teenagers of the messaging of this. Fingers crossed it doesn’t affect anyone negatively.’

While it’s true, we’re not going to know the whole vibe of the show, whether it’s dangerous for self-esteem and body image or not, Channel 4 said of the series: ‘From bum-lifts to nose jobs, sculpted abs to breast enlargements, The Surjury allows people to explore their choices more thoroughly.’

While Ross McCarthy, executive producer for show creators Gobstopper Television, added: ‘This is a totally new way of doing peer-to- peer advice.

‘Our pitchers will either get the surgery they’ve always wanted, or a massive boost in confidence when the public rules they don’t need work at all!’

As the stars went head to head over the show, Channel 4 defended the premise amidst the controversy, saying: ‘Rather than wag a disapproving finger, this new series looks at who wants it, and why – and allows those who make a strong enough case to their peers, to undergo the procedure of their choice.

Advertisement

‘The show will neither glamorise nor condemn their choices: the aim is instead to interrogate the realities.

‘All contributors featured in the series have actively been seeking surgery of their own accord.’

Guess we’ll just have to wait and see.

The Surjury airs in 2020 on Channel 4.
